Webkins and

> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Sorry for delay in replying to this post, but the best game I've seen
my two play is "Toontown", really funny, can meet other friends
online, safe as any game can be and full of jokes that can be
memorised and repeated to friends. My girls are 9 and 11 so this
may be just what you are looking for. Another game they enjoyed, but
passed over when they discovered toontown, was "Virtual Villagers"
which is through "Arcadetown".

Hope this helps

Julie

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Looking for online video game suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: ... Jayn just got a Shining Stars toy (about $15), which is similar to her Webkinz animals. The owners get to name a star, choosing the constellation area of
messages.messageBody:
<<<<<> Not sure if anybody already mentioned Neopets? Even "I" got a neopet
> and played lots of games there. Really fun - lots of variety. >>>

Jayn just got a "Shining Stars" toy (about $15), which is similar to her
Webkinz animals. The owners get to name a star, choosing the constellation
area of the sky, with the Star Registry. They have a website with games and
activities. Jayn is really enjoying editing 60 second movies from a bunch of
choices of scenes, graphics and music tracks available. We still have a ways
to go exploring all the activities available there.

Robyn L. Coburn

messages.messageBody:

freearcade.com
addictinggames.com
cartoonnetwork.com
disney.com and disneychannel.com
(those are the heavily used ones on Hayden's favorites list ;D)
Second the votes for neopets and runescape :)
--
~diana :)
xoxoxoxo
hannahbearski.blogspot.com

messages.subject: Re: Looking for online video game suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: Not in our house!  My 8 yo liked the battle element of it, so I d sit and find
messages.messageBody:
<<I like Bookworm Adventures, but it is definitely for readers
Robyn L. Coburn>>

Not in our house! My 8 yo liked the battle element of it, so I'd sit
and find words for him, easy at first, and he'd try spelling them (I
tried to find phonetic words) and I'd help however he wanted,
sometimes telling him the letters, sometimes saying sounds slowly,
sometimes pointing and clicking. He's on his way to reading and
writing this way, now sounding out names of items he picks up in
World of Warcraft. Not something I planned, but what worked cause he
liked the graphics! (And not that I'm endorsing phonics - it's just
what worked for him.)

Oh, another online game I recently learned of and thought was way
cool was http://linerider.com/ . Does anyone know if the physics of
that is accurate?

Pam

Pam




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

and played lots of games there. Really fun - lots of variety.

-pam

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Looking for online video game suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: My 11 year old daughter loves Furcadia--it s an rpg.  She could spend hours there--in fact it s fun, safe, and very educational (perhaps not intentionally,
messages.messageBody:
My 11 year old daughter loves Furcadia--it's an rpg. She could spend hours there--in fact it's fun, safe, and very educational (perhaps not intentionally, lol). Through this game she has been inspired to learn to do computer graphics and art, her verbal and written skills have zoomed to the point that her descriptive writing is beautiful and rich, a wonder to behold. Plus as a rather shy girl she is learning to socialize with different types of people from aroudn the world.

It's totally free, too.

Mary

----- Original Message ----
From: Lisa Heyman <Lmanathome@...>
To: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com; RUL@yahoogroups.com; RadicalUNschoolersinNY@yahoogroups.com; AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, November 5, 2007 10:42:49 PM
Subject: [AlwaysLearning] Looking for online video game suggestions













Local unschooling friend looking for online video games. Any one have some

recommendations I can pass along?



Lisa Heyman



_____



From: hudson_valley_ unschoolers



Hi All...



Wondering if anyone could suggest an online video game for ds, age 9 and dd,

age 11. They're not into war games, are on quite often with Webkins and

other favorites are the likes of Sonic the Hedgehog and Avitar.



Any suggestions would be much appreciated.

Thanks...

messages.subject: RE: [AlwaysLearning] Looking for online video game suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: We enjoyed www.bigfishgames.com.  There are tons of games to choose from and you can play each game for an hour free to see if you want to own it.  Also, if
messages.messageBody:
We enjoyed www.bigfishgames.com. There are tons of games to choose from
and you can play each game for an hour free to see if you want to own
it. Also, if you agree to buy a certain number of games over 6 months
or a year, the price is pretty reasonable. Some of our favorites
include Insaneaquarium, Wonderland Adventures and Snailmail.

We also like Club Penguin and Dragon Fable. Depending on the age of
your children, Webkinz is also fun (you need to purchase a Webkinz
stuffed animal to get the code to play.) The animals run from $10 -
$15.00 and each pet gives you a one year membership to the site.

messages.subject: RE: [AlwaysLearning] Looking for online video game suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: My dd s recommend Club Penguin, neopets, or Runescape. There is a lot to do on Runescape that in not fighting.  You can cook and make tools, do quests, etc.
messages.messageBody:
My dd's recommend Club Penguin, neopets, or Runescape. There is a lot to do
on Runescape that in not fighting. You can cook and make tools, do quests,
etc.



Angela Shaw

game-enthusiast@...

www.ourbigslife.blogspot.com









[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Looking for online video game suggestions
messages.msgSnippet: Wondering if anyone could suggest an online video game for ds, age 9 and dd, ... Jayn likes all the free games at www.everythinggirl.com which is the
messages.messageBody:
<<<<> Wondering if anyone could suggest an online video game for ds, age 9
and dd,
> age 11. They're not into war games, are on quite often with Webkins and
> other favorites are the likes of Sonic the Hedgehog and Avitar.>>>

Jayn likes all the free games at www.everythinggirl.com which is the Mattel
site - Barbie, Polly Pocket, My Scene, Kelly, Pixel Chix. We bought and
downloaded Diner Dash which Jayn also likes. It has a free trial version
(but I don't have the link - it's on Jayn's computer - so please use
Google.)

I like Bookworm Adventures, but it is definitely for readers.

Robyn L. Coburn
